subject: torts
tested_rule: Warnings don't replace remediation; ordinance may set standard
fact_pattern: At a street food fair, vendor Rowan displays a prominent 'Caution: Wet Area' sign near a drink station. A local ordinance requires vendors to keep walking surfaces 'reasonably dry' and to 'promptly remedy spills.' Multiple cups spill during a rush; Rowan does not mop for ten minutes, and a patron slips and fractures a wrist. The defense offers evidence of full compliance with industry best-practice signage. The plaintiff sues in negligence. The timeline, roles, and governing standards are undisputed; the dispute turns on the precise doctrinal element.

options.A: No liability because compliance with industry custom defeats negligence.
options.B: No liability because compliance with industry custom defeats negligence.
options.C: No liability because the sign shifts the risk to patrons who proceed.
options.D: Liability is likely: warnings don't replace the duty to remediate; ordinance noncompliance supports negligence (possibly per se).

why_correct: Custom evidence is not conclusive; statutory/ordinance standards can establish duty/breach. Failure to clean promptly is the breach.

why_others_wrong.A: Custom is relevant but not dispositive.
why_others_wrong.C: Assumption of risk requires knowing, voluntary encounter of a specific risk; signage alone is insufficient.
why_others_wrong.D: Constructive notice can suffice; their own station created the hazard.

subject: torts
tested_rule: Warnings don't replace remediation; ordinance may set standard
fact_pattern: At a street food fair, vendor Cameron displays a prominent 'Caution: Wet Area' sign near a drink station. A local ordinance requires vendors to keep walking surfaces 'reasonably dry' and to 'promptly remedy spills.' Multiple cups spill during a rush; Cameron does not mop for ten minutes, and a patron slips and fractures a wrist. The defense offers evidence of full compliance with industry best-practice signage. The plaintiff sues in negligence. The timeline, roles, and governing standards are undisputed; the dispute turns on the precise doctrinal element.

options.A: Liability is likely: warnings don't replace the duty to remediate; ordinance noncompliance supports negligence (possibly per se).
options.B: No liability because compliance with industry custom defeats negligence.
options.C: No liability because the sign shifts the risk to patrons who proceed.
options.D: No liability unless the patron proves the vendor actually knew of each individual spill.

why_correct: Custom evidence is not conclusive; statutory/ordinance standards can establish duty/breach. Failure to clean promptly is the breach.

why_others_wrong.A: Custom is relevant but not dispositive.
why_others_wrong.C: Assumption of risk requires knowing, voluntary encounter of a specific risk; signage alone is insufficient.
why_others_wrong.D: Constructive notice can suffice; their own station created the hazard.
